Unraveling the role of basic sites in the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid over Ni-based catalysts Yixuan Wang Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Conceptualization Hongyan Ban Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Conceptualization Yugao Wang Methodology Investigation Ruwei Yao Methodology Investigation Conceptualization Shimin Zhao Methodology Investigation Jiangliang Hu Methodology Investigation Congming Li Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, College of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, China State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization College of Chemical Engineering and Technology Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan 030024 China State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, College of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The weak basic site is the primary puller of the reaction process, while medium basic sites guarantee fundamental catalytic activity. The weak and medium basic sites synergistically catalyze the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid. Basic sites profoundly affect the mode and strength of CO2 adsorption in the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid (FA), however, the mechanism by which the quantities and strength of basic sites affect the reaction process is not yet clear. Herein, a Ni/MgaAlOx catalyst has been developed and the basic sites of the catalyst can be modulated by simply altering the Mg/Al ratio. Through a series of characterizations and experiments, it was observed that weak and medium basic sites synergistically catalyzed the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid, and a reasonable number of weak basic sites can improve reaction performance when a sufficient number of medium basic sites guarantee the fundamental catalytic activity. Moreover, the number and distribution of basic sites are also tightly related to metal-support interactions. This strategy provides theoretical guidance and a feasible scheme for optimizing the performance of non-precious metal heterogeneous catalysts. Keywords Basic sites Mg/Al ratio CO2 hydrogenation Formic acid Metal-support interactions Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogenation of carbon dioxide (CO2) to formic acid (FA), an important chemical raw material[1,2], and a nontoxic liquid organic hydrogen carrier (LOHC)[3–5], is an attractive atom-economic route for the valued-added utilization of CO2. However, there are still several huge challenges in CO2 hydrogenation to FA. Because of the extraordinarily high thermal stability of CO2, the CO2 hydrogenation to FA reaction is subject to severe thermodynamic limitations (eq.1). Therefore, it is typically necessary to add an alkaline solution to the reaction system to overcome the thermodynamic restrictions (eq.2).[6–10] Due to the excellent CO2 capture ability of the organic alkaline solution[8,9,11,12], research on homogeneous catalysts, such as high-performing Ru, Ir-based catalysts[13–16], and relatively inexpensive non-precious metal homogeneous catalysts like Fe, Cu[17–20], have accordingly advanced considerably.[21] However, the toxicity and high separation costs associated with homogeneous catalysts pose difficulties to the industrialization of the process[22]. In contrast, researchers have become interested in the benefits of heterogeneous catalysts in terms of environmental friendliness and simplicity of separation.[23] (1) C O 2 ( g ) + H 2 ( g ) ↔ H C O O H ( l ) Δ r G 298 K θ = 32.9 k J · m o l - 1 (2) C O 2 ( g ) + H 2 ( g ) + b a s e ↔ H C O O H · b a s e Δ r G 298 K θ = - 9.5 k J · m o l - 1 CO2 adsorption plays a crucial role in gas–liquid multiphase reaction systems, especially the CO2 hydrogenation to FA reaction.[24,25] In these reaction processes, both the quantity and strength of basic sites impact the adsorption capability of the C = O bond, resulting in the formation of distinct adsorbed intermediates.[26] Strong basic sites easily hydrogenate CO2 to produce carboxylate intermediates (COOH*), which is more likely to be converted to CH4.[27] On the other hand, CO2 adsorbed at the weak basic site prefers to be hydrogenated to generate formate intermediates (HCOO*) that can further dehydrogenate to form CO.[28] Despite the various approaches available for modifying the basic sites, such as alkali metal doping[29,30], changing the crystalline phase structure of the oxide[31], etc., it is still greatly challenging to modulate the quantity and strength of basic sites on the supported catalyst to precisely control the CO2 hydrogenation products. It is crucial to quantitatively control the basic sites to explore the relationship between the properties of the basic sites and the reaction performance. In our work, we used MgO (basic) and Al2O3 (amphoteric) to regulate the properties of the basic site[32], specifically, the number of basic sites of Mg-Al mixed oxides has been found to correspond well with the Mg/Al ratio[33]. Thus, simply changing the Mg/Al ratio can effectively control the quantities and strength of the catalysts' basic sites. Building upon these findings, our study aims to investigate the utilization of Mg-Al mixed oxides to control the properties of the basic sites, thereby enabling the preparation of efficient and stable catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation reactions. Herein, we prepared a Ni/MgaAlOx catalyst that uses Mg-Al mixed oxide as a support. We discovered that the metal-support interactions (MSI) of the catalysts became stronger as the Mg/Al ratio increased, and the catalysts with stronger MSI generally possessed more weak and medium basic sites. The qualities of weak basic sites are essential for boosting the reaction's high activity performance, and the presence of medium basic sites serves as the foundation of reaction performance. When Mg/Al = 0.2, the Ni/Mg0.2AlOx catalyst could achieve a formate reaction yield of 41.0 % and a rate of 518.4 mg⋅gcat −1⋅h−1 under reaction conditions of 100 °C, 4 MPa. 2 Experiment section 2.1 Materials All chemicals were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O), Aluminum nitrate (Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O), Sodium hydroxide (NaOH), Sodium carbonate (Na2CO3), and Sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3), were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Magnesium nitrate (Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O) were purchased from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Ni Power (Ni) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Deionized water was used throughout this study. 2.2 Preparation of Ni/MgaAlOx catalysts Referring to the mature preparation methods of previous researchers,[32,34–36] a typical example for Ni/Mg0.2AlOx catalyst is as follows. Al(NO3)3⋅9H2O (14.08 g), Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (1.92 g) and Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (4.36 g) were dissolved in deionized water (100 mL), denoted as solution A (Ni: Mg: Al = 2:1:5, mole ratio). A second aqueous solution (60 mL) of Na2CO3 (3.71 g) and NaOH (3.20 g) was prepared, denoted as solution B. Solution B was heated to 80 °C before injecting solution A into it at a rate of 1.5 mL/min under vigorous stirring. An additional small amount of solvent B was then added to the mixture to adjust the pH to 7. After aging at 65 °C for 12 h, the turquoise slurry was cooled to room temperature, filtered, washed with a large amount of deionized water, and dried overnight at 110 °C. Ni-Mg-Al precursors were calcined at 550 °C under an air atmosphere for 4 h. The resultant oxide was then reduced for 6 h at 650 °C under a 10 %H2/Ar atmosphere to obtain a black sample powder, denoted as Ni/Mg0.2AlOx. The aforementioned method was also used to produce Ni/MgaAlOx catalysts with various Mg/Al ratios (Mg/Al = 0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, 5, with the molar loading of Ni regulated at 0.25). The actual Ni loading and Mg/Al ratios in all samples are shown in Table. S1. 2.3 Characterization of catalyst The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a TD-M001 diffractometer at a scanning speed of 8 ◦/min in the 2θ range of 5◦–80◦ at room temperature. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and X-ray excitation Auger spectroscopy (XAES) analysis were performed on an ESCALab 250Xi spectrometer using a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source (hʋ=1486.6 eV). All binding energies were referenced to the C1s peak (284.8 eV). The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were acquired with model JEM 2100F03030708 operated at 100 kV. Raman spectroscopy (Raman) was obtained by using a RENISHAW in Via Reflex Raman spectrometer with a solid-state 514 nm solid-state laser. H2 and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD, CO2-TPD) measurements were performed on the FINESORB-3010 equipment. After removing water and cooling down to 50 °C, H2 or CO2 was introduced to adsorb for 1 h. Ar or N2 was used to purge for 30 min to remove the surface physical adsorption until the baseline was stable. Afterward, the desorption process underwent at the temperature ranging from 50 to 950 °C. Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was also performed on the FINESORB-3010 equipment within the temperature range of 0 °C to 950 °C. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy (in situ- DRIFTS) was performed on a Nicolet iS50 DRIFTS spectrometer equipped with a high temperature DRIFTS reaction cell (Brucker Inc) using an MCT/A detector in the series mode with 32 ∼ 256 scans and at a resolution of 4 cm−1. In situ DRIFTS of CO2 and H2 stepwise experiments, the catalyst (50 mg) was pretreated under an Ar atmosphere at 100 °C for 1 h. Then the CO2 was admitted into the cell (10 mL/min) and the DRIFTS spectra were continuously recorded for 40 min. Afterward, the reaction cell was purged by Ar (20 mL/min) for 15 min to remove the CO2 gas in the cell. Finally, H2 (10 mL/min) was passed into the cell, while the DRIFTS spectra were continuously recorded for 40 min. The system was maintained at 100 °C for the whole measurement. Nickel metal content and Mg/Al ratio were quantified using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, Agilent 720). 2.4 Catalytic tests In this typical hydrogenation reaction experiment, NaHCO3 solution was used to simulate the case of CO2 dissolved in lye (Fig. S1) [32,37–39], Typically, the catalyst (0.1 g) and 1 M NaHCO3 aqueous solution (15 mL) were loaded into an autoclave, then a flow of 0.5 MPa H2 was passed to replace the gas three times, subsequently, the pressure was increased to 4.0 MPa of H2. The system was heated to 100 °C and stirred for 8 h under 900 rpm. The yield of FA was determined by High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) using an Agilent 1260 instrument equipped with an Agilent ZORBAX SB-C18 Analysis Column. 20 mM KH2PO4 (add 1g H3PO4 to maintain pH = 2.2) and chromatographic grade methanol were used as mobile phase at 40 °C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance The reactivity performances of Ni/MgaAlOx catalysts with varied Mg/Al ratios are shown in Fig. 1 a. It has been observed that a slight increase in the Mg/Al ratio might somewhat promote the reactivity performance. Among them, the best reactivity was observed when Mg/Al = 0.2, and the FA yield of Ni/Mg0.2AlOx reached 41.0 %, which was 26.9 % higher compared to 32.3 % of Ni/Mg0AlOx (Table. S2). Interestingly, however, the activity declined as the Mg/Al ratio continued to rise, and once Mg/Al > 1, the reaction performance was less than that of Ni/Mg0AlOx (Table S2). This decline in activity can be attributed to two causes. Firstly, when the Mg/Al ratio was excessive, the interaction force between metal Ni and the support increased, which was unfavorable to the activation of H2 [40–43]; secondly, the amount of basic metal MgO gradually increased, which increased the catalyst's ability for CO2 adsorption. However, too weak CO2 adsorption capacity was detrimental to CO2 activation, while excessively strong CO2 adsorption was negative to the desorption of the CO2 adsorption species.[27,44–46] The rate of formate production increased with rising temperature (Fig. 1c). The production of formate reached equilibrium at around 10 h and could be stably kept in a prolonged reaction time of 24 h without decomposition or further hydrogenation of the formate (Fig. 1b). After five reaction cycles, a marginal decrease of the FA generation rate over the Ni/Mg0.2AlOx catalyst occurred (Fig. 1d). Compared to the fresh catalyst, the reaction activity of the spent Ni/Mg0.2AlOx catalyst decreased by roughly 18.0 % (based on formate yield, Table. S3), indicating the acceptable recycling stability of Ni/Mg0.2AlOx catalyst. The detailed analysis will be conducted through the subsequent characterization. 3.2 Structural characterization In order to analyze the impact of the Mg/Al ratio on the structural crystalline phase of the catalyst, the XRD patterns of both the precursor (Ni/MgaAlOx) and the reduced catalyst were examined (Fig. 2 ). The precursor contains a large amount of Ni-Al or Mg-Al layered hydrotalcite structure, which was evidenced as the main diffraction peaks (003 crystal plane at 11.44°, 006 crystal plane at 23.20°, and 009 crystal plane at 34.88°) of the precursor (Fig. 2a) basically in line with those of the standard hydrotalcite (ISCD#35–0964, ISCD#48–0594)[47,48]. Furthermore, XRD spectra of the reduced catalyst (Fig. 2b) revealed that the dominant phase of Ni was Ni0 (44.51°, ISCD#04–0850). Besides, with an increase in the Mg/Al ratio, the characteristic peaks of MgaAlOx (42.97°, ISCD#33–0853) and NiO (43.29°, ISCD#44–1159) became more prominent. Following H2-TPR (Fig. S2) characterization, we discovered that when the Mg/Al ratio rose, the catalyst's reduction temperature increased, indicating that the MgaAlOx supports with a higher Mg/Al ratio exhibit stronger MSI with the active central Ni, as well as a more stable structure.[49–51]. TEM was used to observe the catalyst morphology, as well as the size and dispersion of Ni particles. As shown in Fig. 3 (a ∼ d), Ni particles were evenly distributed on the surface of MgaAlOx support, and the Mg component marginally decreased the particle size, but there was no noticeable trend in particle size within the error range as the Mg/Al ratio increased. All particle sizes remained between 12 ∼ 16 nm (Fig. 3(e ∼ h)). Lattice fringes were seen on all Ni/MgaAlOx catalysts (Fig. i ∼ l) with the lattice distances being close to the Ni (111) crystal plane (0.203 nm).[52–55] This indicated that Ni monomers mostly existed in the form of Ni0, which was consistent with the XRD patterns (Fig. 2b). Generally, smaller metallic Ni nanoparticles (<7 nm) possessed stronger hydrogenation capabilities and are ideal for CO2 methanation[56,57]. The slightly larger metal particles (>7 nm), on the other hand, restricted the further hydrogenation of formate intermediates while maintaining integral CO2 hydrogenation activation capability, thereby facilitating CO2 hydrogenation to FA.[58]. The catalyst's reduction temperature rose steadily as the Mg/Al ratio rose before dropping sharply and suddenly at a Mg/Al ratio of 5, as shown in the H2-TPR profile (Fig. S2). This suggested that raising the Mg/Al ratio within a certain range enhanced the strength of MSI. The catalyst's crystalline phase structure and the electron transfer between the active center and the support were impacted by the progressive MSI strength[59–61]. The gradually increasing MSI made the catalyst structure more stable. Secondly, the electron transfer between the metal and the support made the active center more capable of activating small molecules, which was conducive to the adsorption of CO2. Additionally, in contrast to fresh catalysts with distributed and uniform oxide supports, supports of spent catalysts had evolved into porous columnar supports. This evolution might be attributed to the memory effect of hydrotalcite.[33–35] When the hydrotalcite precursor has been calcined and reduced, the original layered structure will be restored after immersion in salt solutions. Furthermore, this memory effect of the hydrotalcite precursor limited the growth of metal Ni particles, the particle size of the catalyst did not change appreciably even after five cycles (Fig. S3a). The valence states of the metal elements on the catalyst surface were investigated using XPS spectroscopy, and Ni 2p XPS spectra (Fig. 4 ) showed that the surface Ni mainly existed in the form of Ni0 and NiO. The binding energies of Ni0 and NiO decreased gradually with the increase of the ratio of Mg/Al in the catalyst. Fig. S4 displayed a clear double peak in the Mg XAES spectra due to the chemical shift in particular Mg2+. These findings indicated the electron transfer between Mg and Ni on the catalyst. Electron transfer resulted in the high electron density of Niδ− and Ni(2−δ)+ which was beneficial for the heterogeneous splitting of H2 and adsorption activation of CO2,[40,62] ensuring outstanding reaction performance. It was also worthwhile to note that as the Mg/Al ratio rises in the catalyst, the electron densities of both Mg and Ni increase, suggesting that O was also an electron donor in this process. However, no obvious electronic shift was found in the O 1 s XPS spectra due to the high elemental O content. Rather, a change in the surface oxygen (Osur) to lattice oxygen (Olat) ratio was noted, with Osur/Olat content rising as the Mg/Al ratio increased (Fig. S5). This implied that the catalyst's crystalline phase structure was influenced by the Mg/Al ratio as well. To further investigate the structural impact of altering the Mg/Al ratio on the catalysts, Raman spectroscopy was collected on the catalysts. Raman spectra analysis (Fig. 5 ) revealed a decrease in the content of pure Al2O3 (The peak intensity of Al2O3 decreases gradually[63]) and a red shift in the scattering peaks of the Ni-O bonds as the Mg/Al ratio increased[64]. These findings indicated that as the Mg/Al ratio rose, more Olat migrated to the outside of the original crystal cell and transformed into Osur, forming the Ni-O-Mg bond, which strengthened the Ni anchoring to the MgaAlOx support. This further explained that an appropriate increase in the Mg/Al ratio also contributed to the stability of the catalyst[45]. Nevertheless, when Mg/Al = 5, the surface Ni0 concentration was extremely low (Fig. 4d) and the Ni-O bond scattering peak underwent a sudden blueshift (Fig. 5d), indicating the formation of an unstable Ni-O-Mg bond that was instead detrimental to the catalyst's stabilization. By combining Raman spectroscopy and O 1 s XPS spectra, we speculated that the ratio of Osur/Olat increased as the Mg/Al ratio increased, and the gradually increasing Osur partly formed Ni-O-Mg bonds to stabilize the catalyst structure and partly participated in CO2 adsorption as a nucleophilic species[65,66], which increased the reaction activity. However, when the Olat was inadequate, it was difficult to preserve the catalyst's fundamental crystalline structure, which compromised the physical stability of the catalyst. From the above structural characterization, we further confirmed that the stable loading of Ni particles on oxide supports required sufficient Al content along with the presence of MgO, as supported by the H2-TPR findings (Fig. S2). It was accepted that the Mg component functions as an electronic and structural promoter in the catalyst, improving both the electron density and lattice structure. The catalyst's crystalline phase structure could be altered by gradually increasing the Mg/Al ratio within a specific range, which can then be used to regulate the MSI for the catalysts. 3.3 Adsorption ability evaluation The activation capacity of CO2 and H2 molecules was investigated by CO2-TPD and H2-TPD techniques. In the CO2-TPD profiles (Fig. 6 a), desorption peaks were observed at both weak basic adsorption sites and medium basic adsorption sites in all cases. It was found that the quantities of weak and medium basic adsorption sites increased initially with increasing Mg/Al ratio and then declined (Table. S4). Additionally, it was observed that the ratio of weak basic sites to all basic sites gradually increased as MSI increased within a certain range (Table. S4). Additionally, the ratio of weak basic sites to the total basic sites (nweak/(nweak + nmedium)) showed a good correlation with the catalytic activity, with a tendency that resembled a volcanic type (Fig. 6b). When nweak/(nweak + nmedium) < 0.63, the reaction rate rose as nweak/(nweak + nmedium) increased; conversely, when nweak/(nweak + nmedium) > 0.63, the reaction rate fell as nweak/(nweak + nmedium) rises. This observation was in accordance with the Sabatier principle.[67] It could be seen that the weak and medium basic sites synergistically catalyzed the hydrogenation of sodium bicarbonate to formate at a suitable ratio of nweak/(nweak + nmedium). The MgaAlOx supports with different Mg/Al ratios regulated the MSI of the catalysts to keep the nweak/(nweak + nmedium) in the appropriate range, thus promoting the formation of FA. Furthermore, as the Mg/Al ratio increased, the desorption temperature of the samples increased within the range of less than 200 °C (weak basic sites). This suggested that MgaAlOx with a high Mg/Al ratio has a positive effect on stabilizing the catalyst's weak basic adsorption sites. The enlargement image of CO2-TPD (Fig. S6a) revealed that the desorption peaks of the weak basic sites were barely visible at Mg/Al = 0 or 5, while they were clearly observable at Mg/Al = 0.1 or 0.2. This indicated that the adsorption strength of the weak basic sites was primarily modulated by the MgO content. CO2 adsorbed at weak basic sites was more likely to form bicarbonate adsorbed species, which facilitates the formation and desorption of formate species and prevents further hydrogenation of formate species[68]. Therefore, the CO2 hydrogenation to FA process depended greatly on the strength and quantity of weak basic sites as well as the ratio of weak basic sites to medium basic sites. By simply adjusting the Mg/Al ratio, MgaAlOx could be used to control the strength and quantity of basic sites, hence regulating the performance of the CO2 hydrogenation to FA process. In order to further investigate the effects of MSI on the distribution of basic sites, Ni/Mg0.2AlOx catalysts were prepared using different methods (physical grinding and impregnation). The structural characterization of Ni/Mg0.2AlOx-I and Ni/Mg0.2AlOx-G is shown in Fig. S7 and Fig. S8. Different preparation methods led to the different interaction between supports and the active centers of the catalyst, thereby causing diverse physicochemical features. The MSI strength of the three catalysts (Ni/Mg0.2AlOx > Ni/Mg0.2AlOx-P > Ni/Mg0.2AlOx-G) could be generalized based on the H2-TPR profiles (Fig. S7d). These results suggested that Ni/Mg0.2AlOx might possess better small-molecule activation ability, which was confirmed by the results of reaction performance evaluation (Fig. 7 a). Ni/Mg0.2AlOx showed the best reaction performance, while Ni/Mg0.2AlOx-G performed the worst, and Ni/Mg0.2AlOx-I was in the middle. Furthermore, the CO2-TPD profiles in Fig. 7b revealed that Ni/Mg0.2AlOx-G primarily contained weak basic sites, Ni/Mg0.2AlOx-I primarily contained medium basic sites, and Ni/Mg0.2AlOx contained both types of basic sites (Table. S5). We can observe that the catalytic performance of Ni/Mg0.2AlOx-G, which lacked medium basic sites, was inferior, but Ni/Mg0.2AlOx-I which had a significant number of medium basic sites depicted the formate yields over 20 %. Furthermore, Ni/Mg0.2AlOx, which had a substantially larger number of weak basic sites than Ni/Mg0.2AlOx-I, exhibited a significant improvement in reaction performance. Thus, it could be postulated that the medium basic sites formed the foundation of the catalytic activity, as the absence of medium basic sites negatively impacted the catalytic performance for CO2 hydrogenation to FA. On the foundation of a sufficient amount of medium basic sites to ensure basic reaction performance, the proper quantities of the weak basic sites can work in synergy with the medium basic sites to enhance the hydrogenation of CO2 to FA. From the above discussion, we could discover that weak basic sites and medium basic sites play a pivotal role in the CO2 hydrogenation to FA reaction process. The desorption peak of the Ni/MgaAlOx catalyst in the H2-TPD images (Fig. S6b) became smaller as the Mg/Al ratio increased, indicating a decline in the catalyst adsorption ability for hydrogen with an increase in Mg content, even the desorption peaks virtually disappeared when Mg/Al = 5 (lower than the instrumental detection limit). Furthermore, in the case of Ni/Mg0AlOx and Ni/Mg0.2AlOx, for example, the apparent activation energy of Ni/Mg0.2AlOx increased slightly, despite the fact that the CO2 adsorption ability increased significantly while the H2 adsorption ability dropped just slightly (Fig. 8 ). These findings were consistent with the previously published data[69], suggesting that the partial pressure of H2 might have a more significant effect on the reaction rate. We tested H2 and HCO3− reaction orders, which were 2.28 and 0.58 for H2 and HCO3 −, respectively, as shown in Fig. S9. The reaction system was actually more sensitive to H2. Activation of H2 at low temperatures and pressures is challenging[70,71], and adsorption and activation of H2 do limit the reaction rate of CO2 hydrogenation to FA. The synergistic effect of the weak and medium basic sites significantly prolongs the reaction process, resulting in higher formate yields, but activation of H2 or reactant diffusion promotion[2,72] may be necessary if the reaction rate is to be drastically boosted. In order to further investigate the CO2 adsorption mechanism, in situ DRIFTS characterization of the Ni/MgaAlOx catalysts prepared by different methods was performed. After feeding CO2, the catalyst surface displayed various types of carbonate adsorbed intermediates. As shown in Fig. 9 a, b, c, all three catalysts exhibited the presence of bicarbonate species (1625 ∼ 1635 cm−1, 3500 ∼ 3750 cm−1)[35,68], monodentate carbonate species (1340 ∼ 1370 cm−1)[73,74], and bidentate carbonate species (1440 ∼ 1480 cm−1)[31,35] appeared in all cases. The bicarbonate infrared absorption peak above the wavelength of 3500 cm−1 was attributed to the adsorption of CO2 by hydroxyl groups on the catalyst[35,66]. Ni/Mg0.2AlOx and Ni/Mg0.2AlOx-G exhibited considerable intensities of this peak (Fig. 9a, b), whereas the intensity of the peak for NiMg0.2AlOx-I was much lower (Fig. 9c). This suggested that the hydroxyl groups on the Mg0.2AlOx support in Ni/Mg0.2AlOx-I may have been blocked or destroyed during the impregnation of the active center, resulting in a low number of weak basic sites. Upon switching to H2, the intensity of all the carbonate adsorption peaks decreased significantly and a small amount of formate intermediate (1550 ∼ 1600 cm−1)[75,76] was generated in all of them. Notably, the bicarbonate adsorption peak of Ni/Mg0.2AlOx-G was drastically reduced compared to Ni/Mg0.2AlOx and NiMg0.2AlOx-I (Fig. 9d). Combined with the previous characterization results, it was assumed that Ni/Mg0.2AlOx-G lacked the protection of the medium basic site (bidentate carbonate), resulting in a serious loss of bicarbonate intermediates when H2 was introduced, and these large amounts of intermediate species were not converted into formate, but rather generated methoxylated intermediates (2700 ∼ 3000 cm−1)[74], which contributed to the extraordinarily low FA yields for Ni/Mg0.2AlOx-G. Combining the aforementioned analyses of the catalysts' adsorption characteristics, we discovered that the efficient catalyzed hydrogenation of CO2 to FA required both weak and medium basic sites. Both weak and medium basic sites were prevalent in the Ni/Mg0.2AlOx catalyst, which was synthesized using the precipitation method utilizing Ni-Mg-Al mixed oxides as a precursor. The weak basic site was the primary puller of the reaction process, while the medium basic site was the crucial assurance of activity. A suitable ratio of weak and medium basic sites can synergistically promote the efficient catalysis of CO2 hydrogenation to FA. 4 Conclusion In summary, this study involved the preparation of a Ni/MgaAlOx catalyst using MgaAlOx as a support to modulate the catalyst's basic sites by altering solely the Mg/Al ratio. By changing the Mg/Al ratio, the catalyst's MSI could be adjusted without affecting particle size or morphology, which in turn modulated the properties of the basic sites on the catalyst surface. The best reactivity was observed by the Ni/Mg0.2AlOx catalyst, with a formate yield of 41.0 % and a reaction rate of 518.4 mg⋅gcat −1⋅h−1. After a series of characterizations and experiments, it was interesting to note that as the ratio of weak basic sites to all basic sites increased, the catalytic performance tended to rise and eventually fall, showing a particular volcanic trend. This indicated that weak and medium basic sites synergistically promoted catalytic CO2 hydrogenation to FA. Under the assumption that a sufficient quantity of medium basic sites ensures the fundamental catalytic activity, an appropriate quantity of weak basic sites further contributes to the hydrogenation performance. This synergistic effect of the weak and medium basic sites may be instructive for the development of high-performance CO2 hydrogenation catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Basic sites profoundly affect the mode and strength of CO2 adsorption in the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid (FA), however, the mechanism by which the quantities and strength of basic sites affect the reaction process is not yet clear. Herein, a Ni/MgaAlOx catalyst has been developed and the basic sites of the catalyst can be modulated by simply altering the Mg/Al ratio. Through a series of characterizations and experiments, it was observed that weak and medium basic sites synergistically catalyzed the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid, and a reasonable number of weak basic sites can improve reaction performance when a sufficient number of medium basic sites guarantee the fundamental catalytic activity. Moreover, the number and distribution of basic sites are also tightly related to metal-support interactions. This strategy provides theoretical guidance and a feasible scheme for optimizing the performance of non-precious metal heterogeneous catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Unraveling the role of basic sites in the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid over Ni-based catalysts
